title: 110_hr270
content: The Act is titled the "Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2007" and includes a table of contents outlining the authorizations of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations is provided to various government agencies including the Interagency Task Force, Secretary of Health and Human Services, Secretary of State, Attorney General, President, Secretary of Labor, Director of the FBI, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Administrator of the USAID. Development. Sec. 110. Effective date; rule of construction. TITLE II--OTHER PROVISIONS Authorization of appropriations for the Interagency Task Force to Monitor and Combat Trafficking, including provisions for juvenile victims and model state legislation. Technical and conforming amendments are also included. Section 113(a) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to authorize appropriations to the Secretary of State and the Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking for fiscal years 2008 through 2010. Additionally, authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services is included. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for the purpose of assisting victims of trafficking in the United States is set at $15,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010. Additionally, a grant program is established with an authorization of $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010 to develop and strengthen assistance programs for individuals subjected to trafficking. The authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for assisting victims of trafficking is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of State. Section 113(c) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to authorize appropriations of $10,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 to the Secretary of State for bilateral assistance to combat trafficking, including prevention, protection, and prosecution. Authorized appropriations of $10,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 to assist in promoting prosecution of traffickers and training activities for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judiciary with respect to trafficking in persons. Additionally, funds are allocated for the preparation of annual country reports on human rights. Authorized appropriations are allocated to the Secretary of State for including additional information in the annual Country Reports on Human Rights Practices, as required by section 104. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations to the Attorney General. Authorization of appropriations to the Attorney General and President for the purpose of assisting victims of trafficking in the United States and foreign countries to meet minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking. $15,000,000 authorized for the Attorney General for fiscal years 2008 through 2010, and $250,000 authorized for training activities for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judiciary for the same fiscal years. Program To Reduce Trafficking in Persons and Demand for Commercial Sex Acts in the United States is amended to authorize appropriations of $2,500,000 for each of the fiscal years 2008 and 2010 for specific activities. Additionally, $1,000,000 is authorized for enhancing state and local efforts to combat trafficking. The Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2005 is amended to authorize $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010 for enhancing state and local efforts to combat trafficking in persons. SEC. 105. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS TO THE PRESIDENT. Section 113(e) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to authorize appropriations to the President for foreign victim assistance, assistance to foreign countries to meet minimum standards, and research for fiscal years 2008 through 2010. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Labor and the Director of the FBI for fiscal years 2008 through 2010 to combat trafficking in persons. $10,000,000 authorized for the Secretary of Labor and $15,000,000 for the Director of the FBI. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Homeland Security for investigations of severe forms of trafficking in persons, totaling $18,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010. Additionally, authorization of appropriations to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. Section 102(b)(7) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2005 is amended to authorize $2,500,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2010 to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. SEC. 110 of the Act specifies that the amendments take effect on October 1, 2007, or the date of enactment, and clarifies that the amendments do not impact funds allocated under previous trafficking protection acts. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include eligibility of juvenile victims of trafficking for interim assistance. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must promptly determine eligibility if credible evidence is presented. The Secretary of Health and Human Services has exclusive authority to determine eligibility for interim assistance for juvenile victims of trafficking. Model state legislation is proposed to define and prohibit acts related to the prostitution and trafficking of children. The Attorney General will create model legislation for states to define and prohibit child prostitution and trafficking. This legislation will be disseminated to state officials and posted on the Department of Justice website. The term "State" includes various regions. Technical and conforming amendments are also included. SEC. 203 of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 and Public Law 109-164 are amended to replace "Committee on International Relations" with "Committee on Foreign Affairs".
